additionalNotes: The function has only one basic block (`bb`), so it is trivially the hottest block. The block performs some arithmetic operations, calculates the size of memory to allocate, and calls `calloc`. Since there are no conditionals or loops in this function, the execution flow is straightforward, and `bb` is executed exactly once per function call.

The function has only one basic block (`bb`), so it is trivially the hottest block. All the operations, including arithmetic, bitwise, and memory access, are performed within this block. There is no branching or multiple paths, so the hotness ranking is straightforward.

- The "hotness" of a basic block depends on the branching conditions and the likelihood of execution. In this function, the branching in `bb` depends on the value of `%arg2`. If `%arg2` is non-zero, the flow goes to `bb6`; otherwise, it goes to `bb13`.  
  - Assuming `%arg2` is more often non-zero (a common scenario in bit-setting operations), `bb6` is likely the hottest block.  
  - `bb13` is the next most likely block, as it handles the complementary case.  
  - `bb` is executed once at the start, making it less hot than `bb6` or `bb13`.  
  - `bb21` is the final block and is executed exactly once after either `bb6` or `bb13`, making it the least hot.

The function has only one basic block (`bb`), so it is trivially the hottest block. All operations, including arithmetic, bit manipulation, memory access, and store, are performed within this block. There are no conditional branches or loops in the function, so the execution frequency of `bb` is determined solely by the function's invocation count.

- The hottest block is `bb5` because it contains the loop body and is repeatedly executed as long as the condition `%i8` evaluates to true. This makes it the most frequently executed block.
  - `bb5.bb3_crit_edge` is the next hottest because it serves as the critical edge for the loop and is traversed on every iteration.
  - `bb3` is executed once per loop iteration, making it less hot than `bb5` and `bb5.bb3_crit_edge`.
  - `bb2` is executed once at the start of the loop, so it is less hot than the loop-related blocks.
  - `bb9` is executed once when the loop exits, making it cooler than the loop-related blocks.
  - `bb` is the entry block and is executed only once, making it cooler than the above blocks.
  - `bb10` is the function exit block and is executed once, making it cooler than `bb9`.
  - `bb.bb10_crit_edge` is the least hot because it is only executed when the input `%arg` is zero, which is a rare case.

The function consists of only one basic block (`bb`), which performs a series of bitwise operations and arithmetic to count the number of set bits in a 64-bit integer. Since there is only one basic block, it is trivially the hottest and the only block in the function.

This function contains only one basic block (`bb`), so it is trivially the hottest block and the only block in the sorted list. The function performs a series of bitwise operations and table lookups, which are all contained within this single block. There are no conditional branches or loops, so the execution flow does not diverge.

This function consists of only one basic block (`bb`), so it is trivially the hottest block. The function performs bit counting by accessing a precomputed lookup table (`@bits`) for each byte of the input argument. Since there are no conditional branches or loops, the execution flow is linear, and all instructions in the block are executed exactly once per function call.

The function contains only one basic block (`bb`), so it is trivially the hottest block. All the operations, including memory loads, stores, and arithmetic computations, are performed within this single block. There are no conditional branches or loops in the function, so the execution flow does not diverge.

- The `bb` block is the entry block and is always executed, making it the hottest.
  - The `bb8` block is executed if the condition `%i7` evaluates to true, which depends on the value of `%arg`. This block is likely to be executed frequently in recursive calls.
  - The `bb11` block is executed after either `bb8` or `bb.bb11_crit_edge`, making it less hot than `bb8` but hotter than `bb.bb11_crit_edge`.
  - The `bb.bb11_crit_edge` block is a critical edge block that simply branches to `bb11` and is executed only when `%i7` is false, making it the least hot.

- The `bb` block is the entry point and contains the main loop structure, making it the most frequently executed block.  
  - The `bb.bb16_crit_edge` block is a simple transition block and will be executed every time the loop exits without entering `bb12`.  
  - The `bb16` block is the final block where the result is returned, so it is executed once per function call.  
  - The `bb12` block is executed only when the condition in the loop (`icmp ne i64 0, %i10`) is true, making it the least frequently executed block.

- The hottest block is `bb20` because it contains the inner loop that iterates over a range determined by `%i21` (derived from `%i12`, which is the result of `atoi`). This block is likely executed the most due to the nested loop structure.
  - Blocks `bb23` and `bb30` are part of the inner loop and are executed frequently as well.
  - `bb17` and `bb19` are part of the outer loop, which iterates up to 7 times, making them less hot than the inner loop but still significant.
  - Blocks like `bb6` and `bb` are executed only once during initialization or error handling, making them the least hot.

- `bb3` is the loop header and is revisited repeatedly during the loop execution, making it the hottest block.
  - `bb13` is part of the loop body and is executed once per iteration, making it the second hottest.
  - `bb9` is also part of the loop body and is executed conditionally, likely less frequently than `bb13`.
  - `bb7` serves as a decision point for the loop and is executed once per iteration, but it is less central than `bb13` and `bb9`.
  - `bb4` is executed only when the condition in the loop is true, making it less hot than the loop body.
  - `bb3.bb7_crit_edge` is a critical edge block and is executed less frequently than the main loop blocks.
  - `bb16` is the function exit block and is executed only once, making it one of the least hot blocks.
  - `bb` is the entry block and is executed only once, making it the least hot block.

- `bb11` is the hottest because it represents the successful path where the file is opened, and subsequent operations are performed. This is the most likely scenario in typical execution.
  - `bb4` is the second hottest as it handles the allocation and file opening logic, which is a prerequisite for reaching `bb11`.
  - `bb14` acts as the final block and is executed in all cases, but its execution is conditional on the preceding blocks.
  - `bb` is the entry block and is executed once per function call, making it less hot than the blocks in the main execution path.
  - `bb3` and `bb10` handle error cases (allocation failure and file opening failure, respectively), which are less likely to occur compared to the successful path.

- The block `bb11` is the hottest because it is the final block where the function performs its main computation and returns the result. It is executed regardless of the branch taken earlier in the function.  
  - The entry block `bb` is the second hottest as it is always executed at the start of the function. However, it only performs initial checks and branching.  
  - The block `bb4` is executed only when the condition `%i3` evaluates to true, making it less frequently executed than `bb`.  
  - The block `bb.bb11_crit_edge` is the least hot because it serves as a critical edge and does not perform any significant computation. It simply branches to `bb11`.

- The block `bb13` is the hottest because it is the final block in the function and is executed unconditionally after both `bb` and `bb5`. It contains the majority of the computation and updates, making it the most frequently executed block.  
  - The block `bb` is the entry point and is executed once per function call, making it the second hottest.  
  - The block `bb.bb13_crit_edge` is a simple transition block and is executed only when the condition in `bb` fails, making it less hot than `bb`.  
  - The block `bb5` is executed only when the condition in `bb` is true, making it the least hot since it depends on a specific condition being met.

This function has only one basic block (`bb`), so it is trivially the hottest block. The block performs the following operations:  
  1. Retrieves a pointer from the `bfile` structure.
  2. Calls `fclose` on the retrieved pointer.
  3. Frees the memory allocated for the `bfile` structure.
  4. Returns `void`.  
Since there are no conditional branches or loops, the execution flow is straightforward, and the block is executed exactly once per function call.

- The hottest block is `bb13` because it contains a loop structure that iterates based on the value of `%i12`, which is derived from `%arg5` and `%arg4`. This loop is likely to execute many times depending on the input values.
  - Blocks `bb15` and `bb17` are part of the same loop as `bb13`, so they are also executed frequently.
  - The second loop starting at `bb20` (with `bb23` as the main body) is likely to execute less frequently than the first loop, as it depends on `%arg4` and iterates in reverse.
  - Blocks like `bb37` and `bb` are executed only once, making them the least hot.

- The block `bb2` is the loop header and is likely the hottest because it controls the main loop iteration. Loops typically dominate execution time.
  - `bb3` and `bb7` are part of the loop body and are executed conditionally, making them relatively hot.
  - `bb14` is executed when the condition in `bb12` evaluates true, contributing to its moderate hotness.
  - `bb12` acts as a merge point for multiple paths, but it is less frequently executed than the loop body.
  - `bb` is the entry block, executed only once.
  - `bb2.bb12_crit_edge` and `bb3.bb12_crit_edge` are critical edge blocks, likely executed less often than the main loop body.
  - `bb22` is the function exit block, executed only once when the loop terminates.

- The hottest block is `bb11` because it contains a loop structure (`br i1 %i13, label %bb14, label %bb22`) and is revisited multiple times during the iteration.
  - `bb14` and `bb20` are part of the loop body, so they are also executed frequently, but slightly less than `bb11` due to loop control overhead.
  - `bb22` is the loop exit block, executed once after the loop finishes.
  - `bb8` is executed once for file operations before entering the loop.
  - `bb23` is the final block, executed once at the end of the function.
  - `bb5` is executed only if the file opening fails, which is less likely in normal scenarios.
  - `bb` is the entry block, executed only once at the start.
